cases.title: Apple Inc. v. Epic Games, Inc., 141 S. Ct. 2332 (2021)
cases.summary: Antitrust case involving Apple's App Store distribution practices and developer commission fees.
cases.fullText: In Apple Inc. v. Epic Games, Inc., the Supreme Court addressed antitrust claims challenging Apple's App Store distribution practices. Epic Games alleged that Apple violated federal antitrust laws by maintaining a monopoly on iOS app distribution and charging developers a 30% commission fee. The Court ruled that Apple must allow developers to link to payment methods outside of the company's in-app purchase system, though it rejected Epic's claim that Apple was a monopolist under antitrust law. The decision has significant implications for digital marketplaces and platform governance.
cases.court: Supreme Court of the United States
legalPrecedents: Illinois Brick Co. v. Illinois, 431 U.S. 720
FTC v. Qualcomm Inc., 969 F.3d 974

impactAssessment.regulatoryImpact: Changes to app store policies required

cases.source: Supreme Court of the United States

cases.title: Schrems II - Data Protection Commissioner v. Facebook Ireland Limited, C-311/18
cases.summary: European Court of Justice ruling invalidating the EU-US Privacy Shield framework.
cases.fullText: In Case C-311/18, the European Court of Justice invalidated the EU-US Privacy Shield framework, which allowed US companies to transfer personal data from the EU. The court found that US surveillance laws did not provide adequate protection for EU citizens' data as required under GDPR. The ruling also placed restrictions on Standard Contractual Clauses (SCCs) for international data transfers. This decision fundamentally altered international data transfer mechanisms and forced companies to restructure their cross-border data flows.
cases.court: Court of Justice of the European Union
legalPrecedents: Case C-252/09, Google Spain SL v. Agencia Española de Protección de Datos
Digital Rights Ireland v. Minister for Communications, C-293/12

impactAssessment.regulatoryImpact: Major changes to international data transfer

relatedRegulations: Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union
cases.source: Court of Justice of the European Union

cases.title: Camreta v. Alford, 563 U.S. 692 (2011)
cases.summary: Supreme Court case on child privacy rights in school settings.
cases.fullText: In Camreta v. Alford, the Supreme Court addressed the question of whether child protective services workers violated a student's Fourth Amendment rights by interviewing her at school without parental consent or a warrant. The Court held that the child abuse investigation did not violate the Fourth Amendment, emphasizing the government's interest in protecting children. The decision clarified the boundaries between parental rights and state authority to protect children, particularly in school settings.
cases.court: Supreme Court of the United States
legalPrecedents: New Jersey v. T.L.O., 469 U.S. 325
Safford Unified School District v. Redding, 557 U.S. 364
relatedRegulations: Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA)
Fourth Amendment to the US Constitution
cases.source: Supreme Court of the United States

cases.title: FTC v. Phoebe Putney Health System, Inc., 568 U.S. 216 (2013)
cases.summary: Supreme Court case clarifying the 'state action' doctrine in antitrust law.
cases.fullText: In FTC v. Phoebe Putney Health System, Inc., the Supreme Court clarified the scope of the 'state action' doctrine, which can shield private parties from federal antitrust liability. The Court held that Georgia's grant of authority to hospital authorities did not clearly articulate a state policy to displace competition in the relevant market. This decision strengthened federal antitrust enforcement against allegedly anticompetitive conduct by private parties acting under state authority.
cases.court: Supreme Court of the United States
legalPrecedents: California Retail Liquor Dealers Assn. v. Midcal Aluminum, Inc., 445 U.S. 97
Parker v. Brown, 317 U.S. 341
cases.source: Supreme Court of the United States

cases.title: Burwell v. Hobby Lobby Stores, Inc., 573 U.S. 682 (2014)
cases.summary: Supreme Court case on religious liberty and healthcare mandates.
cases.fullText: In Burwell v. Hobby Lobby, the Supreme Court held that closely held corporations cannot be required to provide contraceptive coverage in their health insurance plans if it violates the owners' religious beliefs. The Court ruled 5-4 that the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) applied to closely held corporations and that the mandate substantially burdened their religious exercise. The decision had significant implications for employment law and religious liberty in corporate contexts.
cases.court: Supreme Court of the United States
legalPrecedents: Employment Division v. Smith, 494 U.S. 872
Church of Lukumi Babalu Aye v. City of Hialeah, 508 U.S. 520
relatedRegulations: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act
cases.source: Supreme Court of the United States

cases.title: Riley v. California, 573 U.S. 373 (2014)
cases.summary: Supreme Court case establishing privacy protections for digital devices.
cases.fullText: In Riley v. California, the Supreme Court unanimously held that police generally need a warrant before searching digital information on cell phones seized from persons who have been arrested. The Court recognized that modern cell phones contain vast amounts of personal information and afford an increasingly integral and pervasive role in daily life. The decision established strong privacy protections for digital information and limited law enforcement's ability to search digital devices without judicial oversight.
cases.court: Supreme Court of the United States
legalPrecedents: Chimel v. California, 395 U.S. 752
United States v. Robinson, 414 U.S. 218
relatedRegulations: Fourth Amendment to the US Constitution
cases.source: Supreme Court of the United States

cases.title: South Dakota v. Wayfair, Inc., 138 S. Ct. 2080 (2018)
cases.summary: Supreme Court decision on sales tax collection by online retailers.
cases.fullText: In South Dakota v. Wayfair, Inc., the Supreme Court overturned the physical presence requirement for sales tax collection established in Quill Corp. v. North Dakota (1992). The Court held that states may require online retailers to collect sales taxes even without physical presence in the state. This decision fundamentally changed the landscape of online commerce and resulted in many states enacting economic nexus laws requiring remote sellers to collect sales tax.
cases.court: Supreme Court of the United States
legalPrecedents: Quill Corp. v. North Dakota, 504 U.S. 298
Complete Auto Transit, Inc. v. Brady, 430 U.S. 274
cases.source: Supreme Court of the United States

cases.title: Association for Molecular Pathology v. Myriad Genetics, Inc., 569 U.S. 576 (2013)
cases.summary: Supreme Court decision on patent eligibility of human genes.
cases.fullText: In Association for Molecular Pathology v. Myriad Genetics, Inc., the Supreme Court held that naturally occurring DNA segments are not patentable because they are products of nature. The Court ruled that Myriad's patents on the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes were invalid, but noted that synthetically created DNA (cDNA) could still be patented. The decision had profound implications for biotechnology and personalized medicine industries.
cases.court: Supreme Court of the United States
legalPrecedents: Diamond v. Chakrabarty, 447 U.S. 303
Funk Brothers Seed Co. v. Kalo Inoculant Co., 333 U.S. 127

impactAssessment.financialImpact: $ billions in biotech sector value changes

cases.source: Supreme Court of the United States

cases.title: King v. Burwell, 576 U.S. 473 (2015)
cases.summary: Supreme Court case upholding federal subsidies under the Affordable Care Act.
cases.fullText: In King v. Burwell, the Supreme Court upheld federal tax credits for health insurance purchased through exchanges established by the federal government. The petitioners argued that the Affordable Care Act only authorized subsidies for exchanges 'established by the State,' but the Court interpreted the statute as authorizing subsidies for all qualifying taxpayers regardless of whether the exchange was state-run or federally facilitated. The decision preserved healthcare coverage for millions of Americans.
cases.court: Supreme Court of the United States
legalPrecedents: National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius, 567 U.S. 519
FDA v. Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corp., 529 U.S. 120

impactAssessment.financialImpact: $ hundreds of billions in subsidies preserved

relatedRegulations: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act
cases.source: Supreme Court of the United States

cases.title: Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission, 558 U.S. 310 (2010)
cases.summary: Supreme Court case on corporate political spending and free speech.
cases.fullText: In Citizens United v. FEC, the Supreme Court held that the First Amendment prohibits the government from restricting independent political expenditures by corporations, associations, and labor unions. The Court ruled that political spending is a form of protected speech and that corporations have the same free speech rights as individuals. The decision led to significant changes in campaign finance and the rise of Super PACs.
cases.court: Supreme Court of the United States
legalPrecedents: Austin v. Michigan Chamber of Commerce, 494 U.S. 652
McConnell v. FEC, 540 U.S. 93
cases.source: Supreme Court of the United States
